vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/10b94f3b-b677-4be8-b134-c9188c35dc9e">WINDOWS</keyword>         <topcClas>Housing</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>The Scottish House Condition Survey (SHCS) is the largest single housing survey undertaken in Scotland and the only national study to look at the physical condition of dwellings as well as interviewing occupiers.<br> <br> The aims of the survey are as follows:<br> <li>to monitor the physical quality of Scotland's housing stock at a national level over time;<br> <li>to contribute to the understanding of the factors which influence the physical condition of the housing stock;<br> <li>to provide a benchmark against which outputs from local surveys can be measured, with maximum flexibility in the areas for which information can be provided;<br> <li>to supplement the system of resource allocation within the Scottish Executive and Communities Scotland;<br> <li>to explore relationships between investment and stock condition both at an individual and national level;<br> <li>to provide an information resource which can be drawn on for policy development in all areas of housing which relate to individual households, dwellings and the relationship between them.</li><br> <br> The 2002 survey consisted of two parts: a social interview (conducted with the Highest Income Householder or his/her spouse) and a subsequent physical inspection carried out by a trained building professional.<br> <br> For the third edition, the data and documentation were updated and two 'Complex Sample Plan' SPSS syntax files were deposited, which may be used to estimate population parameters (see User Guide for full details). Stata and tab-delimited data users should note that although these syntax files are included in the download zip files for each format, it may be necessary to download the SPSS version of the dataset if the syntax files cannot be adapted successfully to run in other data analysis software programs.</abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br>The social interview covered a range of topics, including:<br> <li>household composition;<br> <li>tenure, previous moves and intention to move;<br> <li>self-reported health status and respiratory health;<br> <li>work done to the dwelling;<br> <li>heating arrangements, their use and costs;<br> <li>housing costs;<br> <li>satisfaction with the home and the local environment;<br> <li>existing adaptations and the need for others;<br> <li>employment status and income.</li><br> <br> The physical inspection focused on:<br> <li>the basic description of the dwelling;<br> <li>the material used in construction;<br> <li>the state of repair of the internal, external and common parts (where relevant);<br> <li>the amenities and services present;<br> <li>heating systems and insulation;<br> <li>whether or not the dwelling complied with the Barrier Free Standard;<br> <li>whether or not the dwelling complied with the Tolerable Standard.</li></abstract>       <sumDscr>         <collDate event="start" date="2002-01-01T00:00:00Z">January 2002</collDate>         <collDate event="end" date="2002-11-01T00:00:00Z">November 2002</collDate>         <collDate>The social survey fieldwork took place from January to September 2002, and the physical survey fieldwork from May to November.</collDate>         <nation>Scotland</nation>         <geogUnit>Local Authority Districts</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Individuals</anlyUnit>         <universe>National</universe>         <universe>Households</universe>         <universe>Housing</universe>         <universe>Dwellings in Scotland during 2002. A dwelling is defined as a self-contained unit of accommodation; structurally separate behind its own front door, with the occupants able to get in and out without passing through anyone else's living quarters.</universe>         <dataKind>Alpha/numeric data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Individual (micro) level</dataKind>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Repeated cross-sectional study</timeMeth>         <timeMeth>this is the third survey in a planned series of five-yearly surveys</timeMeth>         <dataCollector>MORI</dataCollector>         <dataCollector>MORI Scotland</dataCollector>         <sampProc>Multi-stage stratified random sample</sampProc>         <deviat>Target: 28549. Achieved: social survey 18417, physical survey (matched pairs) 15168. Weighted sample size: 2192246</deviat>         <collMode>Face-to-face interview; Physical measurements</collMode>         <collMode>physical measurements carried out by housing surveyor</collMode>         <sources />         <weight>Weighting factors used: unitary authority, tenure, date of construction, housing type and non-response. Grossed to total number of occupied dwellings as reported by the 2001 Census</weight>         <cleanOps>B</cleanOps>       </dataColl>     </method>     <dataAccs>       <setAvail>         <accsPlac>UK Data Service</accsPlac>       </setAvail>       <useStmt>         <specPerm>Available to all registered users for any use</specPerm>         <restrctn>The depositor has specified that registration is required. Available to all registered users. The depositor may be informed about usage.</restrctn>         <contact><a href=http://www.ukdataservice.ac.uk/help/get-in-touch.aspx>Get in touch</a></contact>       </useStmt>     </dataAccs>     <othrStdyMat>       <relStdy>3314 Scottish House Condition Survey, 1991 </relStdy>       <relStdy>3795 Scottish House Condition Survey, 1996 </relStdy>       <relPubl>Communities Scotland (2003) <i>Scottish House Condition Survey 2002</i>, Edinburgh: Scottish Executive.
